questions.text: In the outpatient department, a female patient presents with arthritis that symmetrically affects multiple joints, including the wrists, hands, and feet. The patient reports morning stiffness lasting for more than 1 hour, and examination reveals swollen and tender joints.
questions.explanation:
Disease

Joint involved & characteristics

Joint spared

Osteoarthritis (Option C)
  • Proximal and Distal interphalangeal joints (PIP and DIP), 1st Carpometacarpal joint, Hip and knee
  • Asymmetrical involvement
  • Wrist and Metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints

Rheumatoid arthritis (Option A)
  • Metacarpophalangeal joint (MCP) - most commonly involved
  • Symmetrical involvement seen
  • Morning stiffness present
  • Distal interphalangeal joints (DIP) and 1st carpometacarpal (CMP) joint

Psoriatic arthritis (Option B)
  • Proximal and Distal interphalangeal joints (PIP and DIP)
  • Pencil-in-cup, telescoping of digits, arthritis mutilans
  • Skin and nail involvement +
  • Ray pattern distribution of joints seen

Description
  • Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a common chronic inflammatory joint disease characterized by symmetrical polyarthritis, tenosynovitis, morning stiffness, elevated ESR, and presence of autoantibodies (RF and ACPA). It’s a systemic condition affecting various tissues.

Causes
  • Genetic susceptibility (e.g., HLA-DR4 association).
  • Immunological reaction involving synovial tissue.
  • Inflammatory response in joints and tendon sheaths.
  • Rheumatoid factors (RF) and anti-citrullinated peptides (ACPA/ anti-CCP antibodies).
  • Articular cartilage destruction.

Stages
  • Stage 1: Pre-clinical- Immune changes begin, detectable ESR, CRP, and RF.
  • Stage 2: Synovitis- Inflammation, vascular congestion, and synoviocyte proliferation.
  • Stage 3: Destruction- Joint and tendon damage, cartilage erosion, and bone resorption.
  • Stage 4: Deformity- Joint instability, capsular stretching, and tendon rupture leading to deformity.

Clinical Features
  • Early: Pain, swelling, stiffness in small joints (e.g., fingers, wrists), especially after inactivity.
  • Later: Joint deformity (e.g., ulnar deviation, clawed toes), restricted movements, and constant ache.
  • Extra-articular features include subcutaneous nodules, muscle wasting, scleritis, and vasculitis.

Named deformities in RA
  • Boutonnière deformity: Also known as buttonhole deformity, this occurs when the middle joint of a finger bends downward, while the top joint bends away from the palm.
  • Swan-neck deformity: This occurs when the base and top joint of a finger bend downward, while the middle joint is straight.
  • Ulnar deviation: Also known as ulnar drift, this occurs when fingers bend toward the outer side of the forearm.
  • Hitchhiker's thumb: Also known as Z-shaped deformity, this occurs when the thumb flexes at the joint where it meets the palm, then bends backward at the joint below the thumbnail.

questions.text: An elderly patient with the presented deformity was brought to the outpatient department (OPD). What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Joints affected

Common
  • MP joints of the hand
  • PIP joints of fingers
  • Wrists, knees, elbows, ankles

Less common
  • Hip joint
  • Temporo-mandibular joint
  • Spares sacroiliac joint and distal inter phalangeal joints.

Deformities in Rheumatoid arthritis
Hand
  • Ulnar deviation of the hand
  • Swan neck deformity
  • Boutonniere deformity

Elbow: Flexion deformity
Knee
  • Valgus deformity
Ankle: Equinus deformity
Foot
  • Hallux valgus
  • Hammer toe

questions.text: A 72-year-old man came with complaints of unilateral knee pain. X-ray examination showed reduced joint space. Histopathological examination of the affected joint is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Radiological features

Pathology

Joint space narrowing

Focal areas of loss of articular cartilage

Osteophytes

Bone growth at the joint margins

Sclerosis of subchondral bone

Sclerosis of underlying bone

Bone cysts

Cyst formation in underlying bone

Bone attrition

Loss of bone

Apparent effusions

Varying degrees of synovial inflammation

Not visible on radiographs

Fibrosis and thickening of the joint capsule

questions.text: What is the current stage of the disease in a patient who presents with hip pain and true shortening of the limb, and is diagnosed with tuberculosis of the hip?
questions.explanation:
Stage

Clinical Findings

X-ray findings

Stage I: Synovitis

(Option A)
  • Irritable hip
  • Increased FABER (Flexion, Abduction, External Rotation)
  • Apparent lengthening due to FABER (Position of ease due to synovitis)
  • Terminal movements are restricted by 25%

Normal or haziness of the articular margins

 

Stage II: Early Arthritis

(Option B)

 
  • Early joint pain, stiffness
  • Increased FADIR (Flexion, Adduction, Internal Rotation)
  • Apparent shortening due to FADIR
  • Gluteal and Quadriceps muscle wasting
  • ROM restricted by 50%

Osteopenia and narrowing of joint space

Stage III: Late Arthritis

(Option C)

 
  • Marked FADIR
  • True shortening
  • Gross restriction of movements (usually >50%)

Marked subchondral erosion and destruction

Stage IV: Pathological Dislocation

/severe arthritis

(Option D)

 
  • Marked FADIR
  • Gross shortening

 
  • Severe destruction and loss of joint space
  • "Wandering/traveling Acetabulum": Pathological dislocation/subluxation due to gross destruction of the femoral head or the superior acetabular margin.

questions.text: A 67-year-old diabetic patient presented with swelling around the knee, restriction of movement and minimal or no pain. The x-ray of the knee is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Cause

Mechanism

Common Joint Involved

Diabetes mellitus (Most common cause) (Option C)

Peripheral neuropathy leads to altered pain sensation and proprioception

Foot

 

Syphilis (Tabes dorsalis)

Neurological deficits affecting joint function

Knee

 

Syringomyelia

Dilatation of the spinal cord; may lead to syringobulbia (if it extends to the Brainstem)

Shoulder

 

Leprosy

Neuropathy leading to loss of sensation

Hand and Foot

 

Meningomyelocele

Neurological deficits impacting joint function

Variable, but often lower limbs

questions.text: Diagnosis of Gout is confirmed by which test?

What is the most probable diagnosis for a 20-year-old male patient who has been experiencing lower backache and morning stiffness for two years, along with bilateral heel pain for the past six months?
questions.explanation:
Definition

Chronic inflammatory disease primarily affecting the axial skeleton (spine and sacroiliac joints), leading to pain, stiffness, and spinal fusion (bamboo spine).

Etiology

Idiopathic; genetic (HLA-B27) and environmental factors involved. HLA-B27 is positive in 90% of cases, but not all carriers develop AS.

Pathophysiology

Inflammation at entheses → Erosive changes → New bone formation → Syndesmophytes → Spinal fusion (ankylosis).

Clinical Features

Musculoskeletal Symptoms:

  • Chronic low back pain (worse after inactivity, better with activity)
  • Limited spinal mobility
  • Enthesitis (Achilles, plantar fascia)
  • Peripheral arthritis (hips, shoulders, knees)

Extra-articular Symptoms:

  • Ocular: Anterior uveitis (pain, redness, photophobia)
  • Cardiovascular: Aortic regurgitation, conduction issues
  • Pulmonary: Apical fibrosis
  • Gastrointestinal: Associated with IBD

Clinical tests:

  • Schober/ Modified Schober test (for lumbar spine)
  • Gaenslen’s test
  • Patrick/FABER test
  • Figure of 4 test
  • Pump handle test

Diagnosis

Based on clinical features, imaging studies, and HLA-B27 gene presence. Modified New York Criteria:

Clinical Criteria:

  • Low back pain > 3 months (improves with exercise, not with rest)
  • Limited lumbar spine motion (sagittal/frontal planes)
  • Reduced chest expansion (relative to age/sex)

Radiographic Criteria (X-ray):

  • Bilateral sacroiliitis (grade 2-4) or unilateral sacroiliitis (grade 3-4)

Radiological Features:

  • Blurring/haziness of sacroiliac joint
  • Squaring of vertebrae
  • Bamboo spine
  • Dagger sign

 

MRI: Early detection of inflammation

Laboratory Tests
  • HLA-B27 positive (90% of cases)
  • ESR, CRP: Elevated during active disease, but can be normal

Treatment

Non-Pharmacological:

  • Physical therapy (mobility/posture exercises)
  • Patient education on disease and exercise importance

Pharmacological:

  • NSAIDs (first-line for pain, stiffness)
  • TNF inhibitors/IL-17 inhibitors (Secukinumab)
  • Sulfasalazine (for peripheral arthritis)
  • Corticosteroids (short-term flare control)

Surgical:

  • Hip replacement (for severe hip involvement)
  • Spinal surgery (for severe deformities/fractures)

Complications
  • Spinal fractures (minimal trauma)
  • Cardiac issues (aortic regurgitation, conduction defects)
  • Osteoporosis leading to fracture risk

questions.text: A patient presented with pain in the hand. The joints involved were proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint, distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint and first carpometacarpal joint. The wrist and metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints were spared. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Disease

Joint involved & characteristics

Joint spared

Osteoarthritis
  • Proximal and Distal interphalangeal joints (PIP and DIP), 1st Carpometacarpal joint, Hip and knee
  • Asymmetrical involvement
  • Wrist and Metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints

Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Metacarpophalangeal joint (MCP) - most commonly involved
  • Symmetrical involvement seen
  • Distal interphalangeal joints (DIP) and 1st carpometacarpal (CMP) joint

Psoriatic arthritis
  • Proximal and Distal interphalangeal joints (PIP and DIP)
  • Pencil-in-cup, telescoping of digits, arthritis mutilans
  • Skin and nail involvement +
  • Ray pattern distribution of joints seen

questions.text: Which joints are affected in a condition where the distal interphalangeal (DIP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints are involved, while the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints and wrist are spared?
Diagnosis of Gout is confirmed by which test?
questions.explanation: Correct Option B - Synovial Fluid A

questions.text: Which of the following statement about septic arthritis is true

options.label: A
options.text: Staph aureus is most common organism in adults

options.label: B
options.text: Incision and drainage done after culture of aspirate and antibiotic for 24 hours

options.label: C
options.text: Kocher’s criteria is used to differentiate from transient synovitis

options.label: D
options.text: Widening of joint space is seen

questions.correct_answer: B. Incision and drainage done after culture of aspirate and antibiotic for 24 hours
questions.explanation: Correct Option B - Incision and drainage done after culture of aspirate and antibiotic for 24 hou

questions.text: How to manage a patient of Rheumatoid arthritis with deformity?
questions.explanation: Correct Option C - Methotrexate with anti-TNF

questions.text: Which joints are affected in a condition where the distal interphalangeal (DIP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints are involved, while the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints and wrist are spared?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Osteoarth

questions.text: Which of the following is the most specific for ankylosing spondylitis?

options.label: B
options.text: Costovertebral and costosternal ankylosis may cause restrictive lung disease

questions.correct_answer: B. Costovertebral and costosternal ankylosis may cause restrictive lung disease
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B -  Definition Ankylosing spondylitis (AS) is a chronic inflammatory arthritis that primarily affects the spine and sacroiliac joints, causing pain, stiffness, and potential fusion of the vertebrae. Onset Usually begins in late adolescence or early adulthood, with a peak onset between the ages of 17 and 45. Symptoms Early Symptoms: Lower back pain and stiffness. Later Symptoms: Spinal fusion, limited mobility, fatigue, and peripheral joint involvement. HLA-B27 Genetic marker often associated with ankylosing spondylitis; however, its presence does not confirm the diagnosis, and not all individuals with AS have this marker. Imaging

X-rays and MRI may be used to assess inflammation, joint damage, and the progression of spinal fusion.

Bamboo spine on Xray

Disease Progression Ankylosing spondylitis can lead to the formation of new bone, causing the spine to fuse in a fixed, forward-bent position. Extra-Articular Manifestations In addition to spinal and sacroiliac joint involvement, AS may affect other joints, eyes (uveitis), skin, and organs, leading to various complications. Treatment Medications: Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs), biologics. Physical Therapy: Exercises to maintain flexibility and posture. Surgery: Rarely needed, may be considered for severe joint damage or spinal deformity.

questions.text: What is the most common form of arthritis?
